message.content:
cs.CG, cs.GR, cs.DG, cs.SY, cs.NA. 

Reasoning: The paper deals with topics related to computational geometry (convex-layer decomposition, grid peeling) and differential geometry (affine curve-shortening flow), making cs.CG and cs.DG the most likely sub-categories. The paper also presents empirical evidence and theoretical arguments, suggesting a computational and mathematical approach, respectively, which could place it in cs.GR and cs.SY. Finally, the paper includes a quantitative analysis of the grid peeling process, which involves numerical methods, potentially fitting into cs.NA.
